title-group.article-title: Moderating effects of gender on the relationship between poverty and children’s externalizing behaviors

author-notes.corresp: William R Henninger IV, University of Northern Iowa, 211 Latham Hall, Cedar Falls, IA 50614 - 0332, USA. Email: william.henninger@uni.edu

abstract.p: Previous research suggests that boys are at a greater likelihood of exhibiting externalizing behaviors throughout their childhood than girls. In addition, previous research suggests that children who are born into impoverished conditions are more likely to exhibit externalizing behaviors than their peers who are born into higher socio-economic conditions. The purpose of this study was to investigate and compare the trajectory of externalizing behaviors between boys and girls. In addition, the effects of poverty on externalizing behaviors by gender were also investigated. The findings suggest that in the sample used for this study, boys and girls were virtually equal in externalizing behaviors from 2 years old through 5th grade. In addition, analyses revealed that time spent in poverty predicted a greater occurrence of externalizing behaviors over time for girls, but not boys. These findings suggest that what has previously been assumed about externalizing behaviors in boys and girls may be less concrete than was once thought. Implications and future research directions are discussed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Early in children’s development there tends to be a greater occurrence of externalizing behaviors than later on in their lives (Blatt-Eisengart et al., 2009; Bongers et al., 2003). Many have attributed this occurrence to the likelihood of children initiating conflict in response to obtaining an object or activity (Rubin et al., 2003). For most children, these aggressive interactions often occur at a high rate until they are around 5 years old (Bongers et al., 2003; Gilliom and Shaw, 2004; Owens and Shaw, 2003). Around the age of 5, most children’s externalizing behaviors begin to decrease (Bongers et al., 2003; Rubin, et al., 2003). It should be noted that some children do not present the typical downward slope of externalizing behaviors and continue to exhibit these behaviors through adolescence (Shaw et al., 2003).

Research suggests that boys are more likely to exhibit externalizing behavior in early childhood through early adolescence (Blatt-Eisengart et al., 2009; Bongers et al., 2003; Dodge et al., 2006; Miner and Clarke-Stewart, 2008; Rubin et al., 2003). Specifically, boys start out with an initially higher occurrence of externalizing behaviors and this difference is often maintained into adolescence (Bongers et al., 2003; Miner and Clarke-Stewart, 2008). Numerous variables associated with boys’ increased likelihood for externalizing behaviors (e.g. temperament, maternal relationships, gender-valued peer interactions) have been identified by various researchers in the literature base (Cillessen and Bellmore, 2004; Marchand et al., 2002; Owens and Shaw, 2003; Rubin et al., 2003).

A major predictor of increased externalizing behaviors found in the literature is low socio-economic status (SES; Knapp et al., 2007). Specifically, children who live in poverty for an extended amount of time are at a greater risk of displaying externalizing behaviors than peers who spend less or no time in poverty (Brooks-Gunn and Duncan, 1997; Mistry et al., 2002). In addition, Duncan and colleagues (2007) suggest that the earlier a child experiences impoverished conditions the greater the likelihood is that the child will exhibit greater externalizing behaviors. It is evident that economic hardship plays a role in a greater likelihood of externalizing behaviors.

Literature investigating the role of gender as a moderator in the relationship between poverty and externalizing behaviors is not prominent in the literature base (Mrug and Windle, 2009). The literature base is split on the differential effects of poverty on externalizing behaviors in relation to gender (Beyers et al., 2003; Mrug and Windle, 2009; Mrug et al., 2004; South, 2001). Beyers and colleagues research suggests that boys from impoverished conditions were more likely to exhibit externalizing behaviors than their female counter parts. However, Mrug and Windle found no difference in the prevalence of externalizing behaviors for boys and girls living in low SES settings. These findings suggest that more research is needed to identify the moderating effects of gender on the relationship between poverty and externalizing behavior.

sec.title: Current study
sec.p: The current study investigates the relationship between poverty and externalizing behaviors by gender. Specifically, the Early Head Start Research and Evaluation dataset allows us to look at the role prolonged time spent in poverty plays in children’s prevalence of externalizing behaviors. A latent growth curve analysis will be utilized to identify the relationship between these variables. From the current literature base, the following hypotheses were created and tested.

list-item.p: Boys will exhibit greater initial levels of externalizing behaviors than girls.
Boys will exhibit greater levels of externalizing behaviors than girls, throughout the course of the study.
As time spent in poverty increases, so will the slope of externalizing behaviors across the measurement periods, for boys and girls.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: This study used data collected as part of the Early Head Start Research and Evaluation Project (EHSRE), which was funded by the Administration on Children, Youth, and Families (ACYF). The EHSRE project is a cross-site national study with the main objective to investigate and assess the impacts of Early Head Start (EHS) on family and child outcomes. Participants in the Early Head Start Research and Evaluation Project, recruited between July 1996 and September 1998, were families who applied for Early Head Start services and were screened to determine if they qualified for the program. Each Early Head Start site was allowed to determine their own criteria, with income (using the federal poverty guidelines) as the primary factor in determining eligibility. A total of 3001 families were originally recruited for the study (Administration on Children, Youth and Families, 2002).

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Data for this study were taken from the Early Head Start Research and Evaluation Project (EHSRE; Administration on Children, Youth and Families, 2002). Participants included in this study were 1067 children from the longitudinal EHSRE study. Participants in this study were included if they had Child Behavior Check List (CBCL) data at the 24-month, 36-month, pre-kindergarten, and 5th grade data points. Of the children included in the study 52.9 percent were male and 46.8 percent were female. The children’s ethnic background broke down as follows: 37.8 percent white or Caucasian; 32.1 percent African American; 23.9 percent Hispanic; and 4.3 percent identified as ‘other’. The vast majority of caregivers at the first measurement point were mothers (99%), with a small amount identifying as ‘grandparents’ (4.8%) by the 5th-grade measurement. A thorough description of the participants’ demographic information can be found in Table 1.

caption.p: Demographic variables of families participating in study.

sec.title: Externalizing behaviors
sec.p: The Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL; Achenbach, 1991; Achenbach and Rescorla, 2000) is a measure utilizing parent report to gauge social emotional development in children. For this study the externalizing scales of CBCL 1.5 years to 5 (CBCL/1.5–5) years was used for the 2 year, 3 year, and pre-k measurement points, while the CBCL 4 years to 18 years (CBCL/4–18) was used for the 5th grade measurement. Items on the CBCL use a 3-point Likert scale, with item ratings ranging from ‘1 = Not true’ to ‘3 = Often true’. The CBCL/4–18 was normed on a nationally representative sample of 2368 children. Test-rest reliability was reported between r = .95 to r = 1 (Achenbach, 1991). Cronbach’s alpha for internal consistency has been reported between r = .72 to r = .96. Support for the construct validity was also provided by correlating the CBCL’s corresponding scales with already established measures (Achenbach, 1991). Correlations between the scales of each measure ranged from r = .59 to r = .89 (Achenbach, 1991). The CBCL/1.5–5 was normed on a nationally representative sample of 700 non-referred children (Achenbach and Rescorla, 2000). The 8-day test-retest reliability for the CBCL1.5–5 ranged from r = .87 to r = .90 for the internalizing, externalizing, and total problem scales.

sec.title: Poverty
sec.p: Annual income was collected from participating families at each of the measurement points: baseline (point at which families entered study), 24 months, 36 months, pre-kindergarten, and 5th grade. The US Census Bureau calculates poverty thresholds based on a family’s income and the number of adults and children living in the household. For this study, poverty was calculated by taking an average of the US Census Bureau’s poverty guidelines over the three years that measurements were taken for each assessment time point and comparing it to what each family listed for their income and number of people living in their household. For example, data for the pre-kindergarten measurement point were taken between 2002 and 2004. An average poverty threshold was created by adding the US Census Bureau’s poverty threshold for number of people living in household by income for the years 2002 to 2004 and creating an average for the 3-year period. A dichotomous variable was coded for each data point, where families falling below the poverty line were given the value of one and families falling above the poverty line were given the value of zero. These dichotomous variables were added together for each assessment time point to generate an overall poverty score ranging from zero to five. A greater score on the overall poverty variable signified that a family spent a greater amount of time in poverty.

sec.title: Missing data
sec.p: For the current study, when data were missing in any of the utilized scales the Full Information Maximum Likelihood (FIML) function in Mplus 6 (Muthén and Muthén, 2010) was utilized to address the missing data. This method of analysis allows for simultaneous analysis of latent growth curves and missing data (Duncan et al., 2006). Duncan and colleagues suggest that the FIML method of missing data analysis allows for acceptable estimates of standard errors when missing data are present.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Initially a latent growth curve model was created for externalizing behaviors measured at the 2 year old, 3 year old, pre-kindergarten, and 5th grade measurement points. Gender was utilized as a grouping variable for this model. The fit indices for this model were as follows; Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA) = .072, Standardized Root Mean Square Residual (SRMR) = .052; and χ2 (10) = 37.6. According to Hooper, Coughlin and Mullen (2008), these statistics all fall into the ‘acceptable fit’ range.

sec.title: Hypothesis 1: Boys will exhibit greater initial levels of externalizing behaviors than girls
sec.p: There was a slight difference between the initial levels (intercept) of externalizing behaviors for females (m = 15.33) and males (m = 14.87; see Figure 1). This finding suggests that in our sample girls exhibited higher levels of externalizing behaviors at the 2 year old measurement point. Though this is a small difference, it is counter to our first hypothesis.

caption.p: Estimated means for boys’ and girls’ externalizing behaviors.

sec.title: Hypothesis 2: Boys will exhibit greater levels of externalizing behaviors than girls, throughout the course of the study
sec.p: Differences were observed between the slopes of externalizing behaviors for females (b = −6.51) and males (b = −6.01; see Figure 1). Males had an initially lower level of externalizing behaviors than girls, and girls had a steeper negative slope. The result of this finding was that girls maintained an average higher level of externalizing behaviors throughout most of measurement points (i.e. 2 years old, 3 years old, and pre-kindergarten), but ended up having the same level of externalizing behaviors as their male counter parts at the 5th grade measurement point. These results were counter to our second hypothesis.

sec.title: Hypothesis 3: As time spent in poverty increases, so will the slope of externalizing behaviors across the measurement periods, for boys and girls
sec.p: The constructed poverty variable was added as a predictor variable to the externalizing behavior model. The fit indices for this model were as follows; Root Mean Square Error of Approximation (RMSEA) =.058, Standardized Root Mean Square Residual (SRMR) =.045; and χ2 (14) = 39.5. These indices suggest that adding poverty as a covariate improved the fit of the model to the data. After adding poverty to the model the intercepts and slopes for females (m = 15.33; b = −6.51) and males (m = 14.87; b = −6.07) remained relatively equal (see Figure 2). However, the relationship of poverty on the slope of externalizing behaviors for each gender was different. For females a significant relationship was found between time spent in poverty on the slope of externalizing behaviors (b = 2.06; p < .001), suggesting that for every additional time point spent in poverty a 2.06 point increase on CBCL scores could be expected. For boys, the relationship between time spent in poverty and externalizing behaviors was not significant (p = .195). In addition, there was not a significant relationship between the time spent in poverty and the intercept of externalizing behaviors for females (p = .067) or males (p = .788). These findings are counter to our hypothesis that both genders’ externalizing scores would be positively related to time spent in poverty.

caption.p: Time spent in poverty as a predictor of externalizing behaviors.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: It is hypothesized that the typical decrease of externalizing behaviors seen in children is due in part to the development of communication skills and increased interaction with peers where appropriate behaviors are learned (Bongers et al., 2003; Cillessen and Bellmore, 2004; Tremblay, 2000). The findings of this study support the prevailing theories, as group marginal means for externalizing behaviors decreased slowly between 2 years to 3 years, and decreased at a steeper rate from 3 years to pre-kindergarten, then displayed the largest drop from pre-kindergarten to 5th grade. The results suggest that externalizing behaviors for children in this sample decreased as they aged, which coincides with the development of communication skills in the general population (2 years to pre-kindergarten) and children’s interactions with peers becoming more skilled (pre-kindergarten to 5th grade) (Bongers et al., 2003; Cillessen and Bellmore, 2004).

A small difference between girls and boys in initial levels and change of externalizing behaviors was observed in this study. Previous research has demonstrated that boys traditionally exhibit a greater occurrence of externalizing behaviors early (2–3 years old) in their development compared to girls (Bongers et al., 2004; Gilliom and Shaw, 2004). However, in the current study, girls showed a larger occurrence of initial levels of externalizing behaviors (e.g. 0.45 points higher than boys at 2 years).

The decrease in externalizing behaviors observed in the present study for both boys and girls is consistent with previous research (Bongers et al., 2004; Prinstein and La Greca, 2004). However, the convergence of externalizing behaviors scores for boys and girls at 5th grade (nearly the same group mean score at 5th grade) is not consistent with previous research (Bongers et al., 2004; Prinstein and La Greca, 2004). As a result, the novel finding of this analysis is the fact that girls’ and boys’ externalizing scores were so close initially (the girls’ group mean was slightly higher than the boys) and remained close throughout the study. This is contrary to the body of literature that suggests boys are more likely than girls to exhibit externalizing behaviors early in their development (Gilliom and Shaw, 2004).

sec.title: Poverty, gender and externalizing behaviors
sec.p: When poverty was added as a predictor it was found that the longer a female spent in poverty, the greater the likelihood an increase in externalizing behaviors over time would be observed. This was not the case for boys included in this study. Members of the sample for this study were eligible for Early Head Start services. This most likely means that poverty was a major factor in their everyday life. The mixed literature on the relationship between gender, poverty, and externalizing behaviors suggested that greater time in poverty may predict a greater likelihood for externalizing behaviors in boys (Beyers et al., 2003). Or, that neither boys nor girls differ in the role time spent in poverty plays on the occurrence of externalizing behaviors (i.e. Mrug and Windle, 2009). However, we could not find a study that suggested girls would be at a greater risk for externalizing behaviors the longer they spent in poverty. As a result, this is another novel find.

It is most likely that poverty in and of itself is not causing the increased occurrence of externalizing for girls. It is most probably that the poverty is affecting something within the child’s life circle that is, in turn, impacting the occurrence of externalizing behaviors for girls. One such possibility is the relationship of poverty to parent mental health (e.g. depression, anxiety) and parent mental health’s relationship to externalizing behaviors cited in the research (e.g. Malik et al., 2007; Owens and Shaw, 2003). Though we could not find specific research suggesting that maternal depression leads to a greater occurrence of externalizing in girls specifically, there is sufficient evidence to suggest disturbances in parental mental health are related to externalizing behaviors (e.g. Malik et al., 2007; Owens and Shaw, 2003). Unfortunately, testing multiple mediators of the relationship between poverty and externalizing behaviors is beyond the scope of this paper.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: Though we feel the findings of this study are quite relevant, it is not without its limitations. The poverty variable for this study was constructed through the use of caregiver reports of monthly income and number of household occupants. Income reporting by participants can often be incorrect because families’ occupations may change frequently. Social desirability may also play a role in reporting higher incomes than participants make. Participants for this study were eligible for Head Start services, meaning at the time of inclusion in the study almost all families were at or below 125 percent of the poverty line (Administration on Children, Youth, and Families, 2002). As a result, most participants in the study did live at least some time in poverty, but a more objective measure of income (e.g. pay stubs, income tax forms) would have been a more ideal way to assess poverty.

The sample selected for this study is a unique sample drawn from a specific sub-population (EHRSE participants). This sample may not be representative of all families living in poverty across the United States. The sample may deviate from US residents living in poverty on demographic variables (i.e. ethnicity) or the externalizing behaviors. Care should be taken when generalizing findings of this study to the greater US population.

sec.title: Future research
sec.p: The major implication of these findings is that they open up to inquiry a long-held belief about externalizing behaviors. That is not to say we are suggesting that girls are now showing higher levels of externalizing behaviors than boys; but that the context in which children grow up, affects children’s likelihood of exhibiting externalizing based on their gender more than was previously supposed. As stated in the literature review, research on the relationship between poverty and externalizing behaviors by gender is sparse. This suggests that researchers should make a concerted effort to test and report findings in this area.

The practical implications of these findings suggest that it is important for healthcare professionals, human service works, and educators to recognize that the long-held belief that boys are more prone to externalizing behaviors may be shifting to a paradigm where both sexes are equally likely to exhibit externalizing behaviors. Diagnosis of externalizing disorders (e.g. Oppositional Defiant Disorders, Attention Deficit Hyper-Activity Disorder) is skewed largely towards males, resulting in a large amount of research on early externalizing behaviors and later disorders focusing primarily on boys (Greene et al., 2002). However, recent research suggests that girls with higher levels of externalizing behaviors coupled with additional environmental (e.g. poverty) and other health concerns (e.g. ADHD) are likely to exhibit more severe mental health issues (e.g. major depression, conduct disorder) in the future than typically developing girls (Biederman et al., 2008; Maughan et al., 2004). As a result, it is important that research be conducted on effective identification and practices for addressing early externalizing behaviors in both boys and girls. In addition, professionals working with children who exhibit externalizing behaviors (specifically those working in high-risk areas) should be trained in these effective practices.

These findings also warrant the investigation of the differential influence (on gender) of variables that mediate the relationship between poverty and externalizing behaviors. More plainly put, efforts should be made to investigate gender differences in how poverty affects variables such as maternal depression, attachment, peer interactions, and how these relate to the development of externalizing behaviors. These findings may suggest different interventions for boys and girls based on what is affecting children’s externalizing behaviors.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: This work was supported by the Administration for Children and Families US Department of Health and Human Services (grant number 90YF0036/05).
